reviewText:
***Disclaimer: Copy provided by the developer***

I love horror. At least when it comes in the form of movies or written stories. And this might surprise some people, but I genuinely lack any positive sentiment towards horror games. The reasons for this are manifold. For one, most horror games rely heavily on jump-scares. And that’s not horror. It’s startling to see a freakish monstrosity jump out at you while your ears get assaulted by a string orchestra going through a meat grinder, yes. But it’s not scary and it’s not horror.

Another reason why horror and games don’t gel for me is that games are interactive. I have agency and I dictate the pacing of a game. I can take my time and explore every nook and cranny, or I can just jog through the level. I simply still have too much control over the game even if I’m completely helpless. And the final reason why I don’t play many horror games is because I’m just staring at a black screen most of the time. Horror games use darkness as a weak setup to hide stuff from the player in order to then build in jump-scares. Again, not horror. Horror is a feeling of underlying dread you get from being exposed to something.

So why did I voluntarily pick Kholat to write a review about? Well, first off it seemed to not engage in all of the tropes mentioned above. Your surroundings are mostly well-lit, it rarely uses jump-scares and when it does, it makes sense within the universe. And lastly, it manages to setup an eerie atmosphere from the very start. It accomplishes this with the fact that it’s an adaptation of a real event that took place in the Ural Mountains in 1959 when a group of alpinists were killed in an unexplained event called the Dyatlov Pass incident. If you want to look it up, it’s a great read and it has all the ingredients to make an absorbing adaptation out of it. Because of its unresolved nature you can spin any yarn you want out of it. And it’s an incident that hasn’t been widely covered a dozen times by other, bigger productions.

The plot of the game takes you to Kholat Syakhl, literally “Dead Mountain”, where you retrace the events in search of an explanation. Armed only with a map, a compass and a flashlight, you set out to traverse the mountains in search for newspaper articles, diary entries and other reports to uncover the mystery of the incident. And you obviously do it all by night.

If you read the above paragraph and thought to yourself “This sounds an awful lot like the Slenderman games”, you’d be in the correct ballpark. You’re running through the wilderness in search of a variety of documents. And there isn’t really much that’s chasing you throughout most of it. Where Kholat manages to really become scary is with its atmosphere. And it does so without artificially putting you in a dark environment. The mountains are brightly lit by a full moon and your flashlight – should you ever need to use it in the bright environments – has no annoying degrading battery that for some reason runs out in five minutes real time.

No, what makes Kholat scary is the fact that it manages to invoke a haunting claustrophobia. Even though ironically most of it takes place outside in the wide open mountain range. Maybe this is a particularly subjective observation on my part, but my favorite horror stories – The Shining, The Thing, At The Mountains Of Madness – all take place in remote, wintry environments, in which the location and the weather themselves are equally as eerie and threatening to the protagonists as the horror that stalks them. The feeling of isolation probably resonates with me a lot for some reason. All that makes me appreciate Kholat far more than most other horror games and it meant I could be fully immersed in its world.

It would’ve been too good to believe however if the game were an atmospheric mood piece for the player to experience without encountering hostility. During our excursions we cross paths with a bunch of specters who aren’t particularly fond of us wandering around. Encounters with them usually only last a couple of seconds, since directly engaging them leads to death. Running away is only a semi-viable option, since running in deep snow is very tiring for our character and they usually manage to catch up.

Besides this, the game does have a few more drawbacks to it. First and foremost, the game contains very little actual gameplay. It’s largely a very literal example of a walking simulator. In addition to that, the game doesn’t give the player a lot of direction. This is especially a problem at the very start of the game. We begin the game at a deserted village without any indication of where we’re supposed to go. The player has to bring his own hunger for exploration in order to eventually find the correct path to the tent where the alpinists found their ends.

But even prior to that, the game puts another obstacle in our way. We find ourselves in a blinding snowstorm in which we’re supposed to find the actual camp of the victims. The whole screen is white, you can barely make out where the ground stops and the blizzard begins, though luckily after a bit of aimlessly wandering around and eventually finding the tent, the weather clears up.

However this lack of direction turns into a strength later on in the game. When we receive the map of the mountain range, a bunch of geographic coordinates have been written onto it. Though you’ll have to figure out where they are yourself, because specific locations only get added to the map once you’ve found them. What turns this relatively simple objective into a challenge is the fact that your own position doesn’t get marked on the map. You’ll have to use the compass and the map itself to keep track of where you are, so it’s vitally important that you don’t become lost.

What enhances the already dense atmosphere of the game is both the phenomenal soundtrack as well as the voice-acting. Sean Bean in particular manages to set the mood very effectively with his calm, soothing voice. But also the rest of the voice-acting that’s used to read the messages you find to you is very good.

People who like jump-scare fests like Five Nights At Freddies or Outlast probably won’t find much to enjoy here. But I can definitely recommend the title to players who like subtle, introspective horror that is more concerned with building atmosphere and a feeling of dread rather than constant tension. With the caveat that Kholat is rather lacking in the gameplay department and unfortunately, the ending doesn’t provide much closure and at less than four hours – even though the developer claims it takes longer to beat – maybe it’s a bit short for what they’re asking.

TechRaptor Review[techraptor.net]

Kholat is a rare type of game – one that challenges you and harkens back to another era in many ways. Kholat is a first person survival horror exploration game based on the real life Dyatlov Pass Incident. Unlike many other “survival horror” games, Kholat isn’t actually an action game or a crafting game with touches of horror.

Instead, Kholat takes you to a beautiful, yet haunting world that heavily relies on atmosphere to create tension. Set in the Northern Ural Mountains, you are there a while after the Dyatlov Pass Incident trying to figure out what happened. With you, you have no weapons, no cell phone, basically nothing other than a flashlight, a compass, and a map that you find. On the map there is a list of 9 coordinates – major locations for you to visit and find out information about what has happened.

Kholat is a difficult game to score because it is one that if it resonates with you, it will be in your game of the year lists I think. However, it is a pretty niche title with the difficulty, the genre, the map navigating and other factors, as well as a relatively short average run time (unless you get lost all over the place like me). If a game that focuses on atmosphere, beautiful graphics and horror generated not through cheap tricks and jump scares interests you, I recommend Kholat wholeheartedly.

Final Score: Very Good 7/10 Kholat is a welcome challenging and atmospheric take on the horror genre"

reviewText:
So, what's Kholat like? I'll tell you.

It's a little bit like Myst. You're dropped into the game's world without even a single hint as to what you're supposed to do. But Kholat isn't a point & click game, and it isn't nearly as frustrating or easy to get stuck in.

It's a little bit like Gone Home. You'll gradually progress through the story in almost any order you like, and try to make sense of the events taking place around you. But Kholat has a more interesting and mysterious story.

It's a little bit like Amnesia. You'll have similar things chase and torment you. But Kholat has stunning visuals.

It's a little bit like Dear Esther. The story segments you come across are as ambiguous, and following visible points of light in the distance tends to be a good idea. But Kholat has actual gameplay, and you can die. You WILL die.

It's a little bit like Cryostasis. It's Russian, meaning it's freezing and it's frightening. But Kholat gives you no weaponry to defend yourself.

It's a little bit like Slender. You'll be collecting a lot of pages out of books, newspapers and diaries. But Kholat does NOT only base itself around this single gimmick.

It's also a little bit like actually hiking in real-life. You can get lost, and it can get frustrating. But Kholat gives you a map and a compass. Use them, don't be an idiot, and this potential element of frustration should be minimal.

If ANY of the above even slightly interested you, then I'd say Kholat is worth your time and money. Check it out.

reviewText:
I'd give Kholat a flat 9/10 and here's why.

It ultimately comes down to a lot of personal preference. The game makes heavy usage of the typical, slow, and unsuspecting explorer, and bases its gameplay on it. It's not a game where you're constantly running away from jump scares like in games such as outlast. If you're looking for jumpscares, this isnt the game for you. It's a more psychological approach to horror. The horror and fear aspect comes from the immersive world Kholat puts you in. The sound of the wind howling, the sound of an old mountain creaking, and the wolf howls in the distance all work together to create a very atmospheric and eerie/dark environment for you to explore. It's very slow paced for the most part, although there are a few faster segments towards the end of the game. The game also explicitly tells you to pay attention to your surroundings, and I didn't truly understand what they meant until I saw massive skulls formed from the rocks, staring right at me as I slowly made my way through a pass.

Pros:
-Incredible detail to the environment
-Eerie sounds make the game even more immersive
-Level of helplesness not as high as say outlast
-Psychological and introspective
-No campaign order (you can travel to any point of interest in any order) Noce for the free roam aspect.
-Relatively smooth (Running an i7-4790k, GTX970) Max graphics (looks incredible) @ 1080p
->Average 55-60 fps w/ v-sync on. Occasional frame-rate drop to 40 (not sure why? Rendering environments-shifting from cave to snowstorm maybe? idk)

-VOICED BY SEAN BEAN! How badass is that?

Cons:
-Nothing to do after you finish the game
-Lacks replay value (wouldn't play this game multiple times as it's essentially the same exact story)
-relatively short game. about 10 hours tops. Sure you can make it last as long as you want if you just wander the paths over and over again.
-Feels like the story is unfinished. The game mentions a lot of really interesting conspiracy theory-esque conversations that don't really give closure to the story (that may just be because of the actual story/inciedent game is based off of.)


TL;DR: Buy this game if you like immersive horror, don't buy it if you want an outlast-esque game.

I definitely reccomend this game if your rig can handle it, and if you're looking for a slower paced immersive game to lose yourself in.

reviewText:
Not a game for everyone. You will love it or hate it. Kholat is a slow burning eastern European style walking game, in which you try to unravel a strange mystery. It is not an American style horror experience with violence, blood and screeching mutant monstrosities. It is all about atmosphere, tension, ambiguity and story with a good mix of eastern European mysticism and surrealism.

I would advise going into the game blind. Dont read some of the longer more detailed reviews, dont watch on you tube, and dont do too much homework on the game. Doing so will spoil the biggest driving factor behind the game: mystery, the unknown and unexpected. This seems like the kind of game that you will know you will like or not.

The game is short, and does not outstay its welcome (unlike some other games of this sort). It has excellent sound design and wonderfully fitting musical track, and very well done voice overs.

My biggest complaint is performance. While my machine does not meet all the recommended specs, I had very low FPS even running with low resolution and low settings. I would have expected to at least run at medium settings with good FPS. Unless there are some performance patches in the future, I might advise avoiding the game if you dont meet the recommended settings, and dont even bother if you only meet the minimum settings. Additionally the FPS difference between running on high and low was fairly small for me, with high being around the 10s, while low in the 20s. (however it must be noted that even low setting still look quite good, though I would love to experience this game again at 60fps and the highest settings)

Despite the poor performance I loved the game, and will probably play it again in 6 or so months. It is a wonderful, chilling and depressing trudge through the snow, truth, reality and the human psyche.

(Video review linked at the bottom)

The horror genre is slowly becoming a mess, games that focus on cheap jump scares are flooding Steam and other services while very few games that are actually “scary” hit the market. Kholat steps away from the “jump scare” subgenre and shows us that there is still some hope for the horror game genre.

Kholat, based on the actual event of the Dyatlov Pass Incident, is a fantastic horror game that shows the industry how a horror game is done right. To give a little bit of backstory, the Dyatlov Pass Incident is an event that happened in January to late February in 1959 when 10 Russian students went on a hike in the Ural Mountains on the eastern side of Kholat Syakhl. After one of the students went back due to illness the others pushed forward and were never heard from again. So a group went to explore in hopes to find their whereabouts. The remaining 9 students were all found dead from various, and still unexplained reasons.

Based off these real-life events the story of Kholat is one of the best stories I’ve heard told in the horror game genre. Narrated by the famous Sean Bean, the games writing, narration, and story are all fantastic. The narration I will say is good, but not the best, solely for immersion purposes. Most of the voice actors seem to have british accents, which works well for Sean Bean but not the others. The diary entries are narrated by a british actor, playing a Russian student. I would have liked to see these entries narrated by a Russian voice actor, but this is just me being nitpicky. I wouldn’t consider this a con, just thought I’d mention it. The sound in this game is excellent, the sound effects and music fit the game perfectly and create very tense feeling situations. One thing I loved was oddly the sound effects of walking in the snow. As a Canadian I can say the developers nailed those sound effects right on the head. The atmosphere in this game is amazing, wandering in harsh mountains has never been so enjoyable. The mountains and caves are all beautifully designed, the various places of interest all feel distinct and unique in their own way. (Mild spoilers here) From burnt and hell-like looking forests to sacrificial altars and abandoned bunkers, these places all hold story significance while providing the tense atmosphere that makes this game true horror.

The gameplay is simple and only requires your inner explorer. You start off in an abandoned Russian town with no markers, no arrows, no nothing. Just your willingness to explore. You will eventually find your way around where the real game begins. You go to a whole new area, deep in the Ural Mountains where you must just simply explore with your handy map, compass, and flashlight. Keep in mind, this area is completely non-linear and open. The map has coordinates of all the places of interest but I found all of these places without any real navigation involved. The flashlight I found to be extremely useless as most areas are lit by the full moon in the sky. I guess if you were playing the game at a low brightness to add to the experience the flashlight would be a very nice touch. The game itself is around 4-6 hours in length and is filled with many little notes and diary entries to collect if you feel like getting more backstory.

Lastly, the performance of this game is quite good, I will say though having to play through the entire game in 30fps was quite annoying. I feel as though my processor was bottlenecking my graphics card in this game, I could play the game on medium-high and maintain a solid 30fps. This game does require a decent rig. The game is powered on Unreal Engine 4 and it looks amazing. I could easily see this game being used for benchmarking purposes.

In most horror games the “horror” is caused by cheap jump scares that startle, not scare. Kholat on the other hand uses it’s interesting backstory, immersion, beautiful yet creepy atmosphere, and fantastic sound to be possibly this years best horror title.

reviewText:
If you don't mind exploring without too much guidance and the limited interactions with the world (all you can do is walk or run - for a limited amount of time - and collect notes to unfold the story), you'll most certainly enjoy the game's atmosphere and graphics.

It's more in the line of Dear Esther than Ethan Carter, but contrary to what The Chinese Room did, you are free to explore the open environment. To do so, you only have a map, a compass, and a bunch of coordinates. The realistic approach to exploration means you don't get to see where you are on the map as in most games.

The Slender-type mechanic is more or less scripted it seems, so you won't be bothered that much except when reaching a newly discovered area, and the threats can be avoided by simply running away, which worked for us most of the time. There are a few instances when you'll die when taken by surprise, but not that much in the 5 to 6 hours you'll need to complete the game.

It's not a game for everyone, but it's a game that deserves your attention in our opinion.

Here is my review in 30Seconds:

https://youtu.be/LcFhhOraIBE

Based on the Dyatlov incident, where 9 hikers were found inexplicably dead in the Russian mountains, this exploration game throws you into one of the most realistic immerse games we'’ve tried yet.

The game just hurls you in. You find yourself all alone to apparently roam aimlessly. But you just have to use common sense, like you would in real life, and follow the road. Then, it gets weirder and weirder as the paranormal horror theme builds up.

There are mysterous creatures that creep on you if you aren'’t careful. After all, this is survival of the fittest. Your ultimate goal is to find what happened in that snowy night. You find scattered notes that slowly let you know more and more of the story. You have a map, a compass and your own orientation skills. Just like real life, there’s no red dot in the map that tells you “you’re here”.

The graphics are beautiful - you wonder how they managed to pull it off so well. But the sound is even better. It makes you feel like you’re there all alone… or maybe not that alone.

You are accompanied by the voice of Sean Bean, who narrates key plot points and a good voice actor makes this an even more thralling experience.

7 chills out of 10

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of Russian Science Fiction and Horror, usually in books and movies, but also in video games like Metro 2033 and the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. So I felt it was my duty to play this game as well, and even if I'm not through yet, I can absolutely recommend it.

Let me state first: This is NOT an Action game! Your only weapon is naaaah, not your flashlight! Put it away 'til you reach a dark cave. It's your stamina, but it's precious and very limited so don't use all at once*! This game bears Exploration game in its description for a reason, it's slow-paced, you're supposed to keep one eye on the compass, and one eye plus both ears on your enviroment - which is fairly beautiful but devastating - otherwise you're gonna overlook something important and/or die. If you're looking for a fast-paced action horror game you can finish as quickly as possible, shooting/beating down all enemies in your way (I've seen reviews comparing Kholat to Silent Hill and stuff...), then please look on, you won't have fun with this one. ;)

The controls are very close to reality. Imagine just for a second you're going on an expedition to the Ural with like -50°C at night - do you go there in shorts and t-shirt with flip-flops on your feet? Really? You're serious? xD Nah, you're not. I'm sure you don't...
So you're wearing heavy winter clothes, maybe even multiple layers, agree? And that's exactly what the controls feel like: You cannot move as quickly as you want to 'cause you're simply wrapped and packed in clothes to avoid hypothermia, there's fresh-fallen snow all over and maybe even ice underneath making it fairly hard to walk fast.

- Is there much to do in this game?
-- No, not really. It's mostly walking, observing your enviroment, sometimes running, finding (reading/hearing) records or hidden paths... And yeah, you might die a few times. That's pretty much all you can do (you might call it a walking simulator with a death feature xD) since it focusses on its story, and it is doing very well telling it in small bites. The biggest challenge is navigation with a compass and map, because that`s all you have beside your flashlight. Regardless of the map and compass you're probably going to get lost a few times. Even with fast travelling between the camp sites you're gonna walk alot, in fact most of the time! You can also try to sprint constantly, but if you're forced to run then, you won't be able to anymore...

- What about the story...
-- I'm not at it's end yet, but it definitly got me hooked after the first hour and I cannot resist playing, I must know how it ends, and how it began! You start hopping off a train in a small, quiet Russian village to find details about the Dyatlov pass incident. It's a beautiful place, so I definitly recommend taking a look around - you're not yet in a hurry. Then you head to the forest. The next moment you find yourself in the middle of a snow storm close to the Dyatlov group's camp on Kholat... The storm is over, you start your investigation. Hard to describe without spoiling too much, so I'll keep it this short ;)

- ... and the atmosphere?
-- It's perfect. A perfect Russian psy-horror theme. If you allow to immerse yourself in the game, the snow and wind will make you freeze. The English voice actors have done an amazing job here, they bring the story to life (I'll check the Polish voices in the next run!). You can feel the desperation in this place, that something evil has happened, and someone or something is lurking in the dark, waiting for you to make only one false step. But most of all you feel lost in the middle of nowhere.

- Is this a Horror game after all?
-- In my opinion it is. Don't confuse Horror with Splatter, please! There are only very few jumpscares though. Therefore the anomaly" poses a subtle and steady threat since you can easily overlook it

reviewText:
Puts the indie horror genre to shame really.

Graphics: Their pretty, and it has a great atmosphere, right at the start, but it gets extremely repetitive after a short time. Every area is just the same. White snow, more white snow, and a snowy cave here and there. The exception is a forest with burnt tree stumps.

Your equipment:

-You have a torch but there is absolutely no motivation to use it because your stuck in a wintry white wonderland, and it doesn't help during the blizzards.

-A compass which is side-on and doesn't prove useful because:

-The map isn't accurate to the trails and doesn't show the proper direction and shape of the paths always. It becomes a guessing game of trust the map, or your gut instinct for direction. The gut is usually more reliable.

-Your an obese individual who can jog for no more than 10m before going into shock and losing vision for a short time. If anything it just stretches out a game which would otherwise be completed in less than an hour.

The horror: Encounters are predictable. It is extremely easy to avoid any confrontation throughout the game, except at a few scripted events which you *almost* can't avoid. There is only one type of enemy. A semi-transparent orange ghost who has the eyesight of a mole. You pretty much have to run towards him within 5m and shine your torch in his face to get his attention...at which point you get an achievement for doing so.

You see him coming (walking with the speed of a tortoise) from far away, giving you plenty of opportunity to open up a can of sardines, make a sandwich, eat the sandwich, then come back to your computer and hit the w key to slowly walk away from the impending doom...

Gameplay/Story progression: The game consists of picking a direction, making your way to a landmark, picking up notes along the way, then repeat. reviewText:
This game is beautiful and haunting. Between the music, the scenery, feeling truly lost, and constantly feeling watched wherever you go, this game is immersive and atmospheric in the absolute best way. This game is horror done right. While there was only one time that nearly gave me a heart attack, every moment of gameplay was tense and uneasy.

Throughout the first hour or so, I honestly had no idea how to navigate. I had no idea where to start or what to look for. But slowly, the game allowed me to learn naturally instead of forcing a tutorial down my throat. Needless to say, by the end of my time on Kholat Syakhl I was an expert navigator. The sense of accomplishment from that alone was extremely satisfying.

In terms of graphical fidelity, this game is very impressive. The textures especially were simply gorgeous. They all look like you could reach out and just feel the bumpiness of the rocks or the grit of the dirt. The mountains give you beautiful snowy forest vistas, while the caves are cold and damp, literally dripping with ambiance.

The soundtrack is quite good, although it's not necessarily one I'd listen to outside of actual gameplay. A couple tracks are sweeping and nice to listen to, but by and large the soundtrack is full of gripping drums and blaring low horns. It does a great job of keeping you always looking over your shoulder. There are some vocal tracks, and they are used appropriately. One at the beginning, one towards the end that fits well with a note you find just before you get a story beat, and one in the credits that, in my opinion, was maybe the weakest of the vocal tracks.

Pros:
Beautiful graphics
Simple controls that do only what you need
Rewarding navigation difficulty curve (maybe a negative for you - YMMV)
Interesting story that ends in such a way to keep you guessing and speculating
Pretty good soundtrack
Top notch voice acting
A lot of content and scenery to discover

Cons:
I might've liked a few more graphical options
Stamina mechanic (though this is just a personal dislike in games, and a minor gripe at worst)
If you're a seasoned horror vet as I am, you won't be scared out of your mind constantly. Look elsewhere if you want that
No manual saving

All in all, this game is an 8/10 from me. Or a must buy. Whatever scoring appeals to you, it's worth a buy, even at full price. This is by far one of the best horror games to hit steam in recent memory, and from an indie studio no less. Thank you, IMGN.PRO, for such an engrossing experience!

I was so hyped for this game. I love exploration and I don't like horror games so I thought this was a good choice for me, given that the game is not incredibly scary (it is still a bit scary for me, but in a good way). Sadly, it didn't meet any of my expectations.

TECHNICAL:

The game looks nice enough. I was so looking forward to a game built and developed on UE4. We have UE4 since years and nobody using it. Unfortunately it is unbelievably poorly optimized. With a 970, it stutters like hell even at 1920x1080 on medium details. Framerate goes from 35-37 fps to 60+ fps for no reason. Shadows glitch all the time.

GAMEPLAY:

Lot of exploration that turns into an extremely boring and long and slow walk. You can fast travel but only to camps you already visited. You can sprint, but only briefly because it's cold and you get tired. If you exaggerate, you have to wait even more because your sight is so blurred you can't see anything so it is even worse. The scenery is all the same, the map system is quite weird because the map does not actually (in my opinion) reproduce exactly every little cranny and path that you can take, making you disoriented. I was expecting a wonderful mix between snowy and icy spots, lost woods, abandoned buildings in small villages.....but no, the whole point in the game is to run (walk) around like crazy and finding some 'hot' spots that will be shown on the map.

Miasmata did that well, with the whole triangulation system. In this game exploration is just hit and miss and breaks immersion.

I hate badly optimized games....there is no reason why the game should run this bad on my system and the developers were just too lazy to even investigate and release some performance improving patch.

So, the game is nothing particularly good, plus it is for sure not well enough optimized, so I don't recommend it.

reviewText:
tl;dr: Beautiful, spooky game set in the mountians with the backdrop of a real mountain tradgey. Map reading and orientation skills a must. Little rough around the edges but for the asking price, wonderful experiance.

First game developed by IMGN, a polish publishing company, which shows a lot of promise. Seemingly stranded on the Ural Mountains, the player is tasked with exploring the mountain range to uncover what happened. A key part of the game is exploration and orientation where the player is given and a compass. The map shows a number of paths around the range and written on the map are a number of cords that the player needs to find in order to uncover what happened in the Ural mountains.

While the game is open exploration and there is no set order that the cords have to be visited in, some of the paths that are on the map are blocked off with knee high walls and are meant to be travelled down rather than up. While many are well designed into the world so not to be too obvious, there are a few moments where it feels like the player is being sent down corridors rather than open to explorer where ever the player wants. It does not have the openess of skyrim, but that would never be a far comparison to make.

While having the invistable walls adds obvious direction, it can take away from the otherwise amazing immersion. There have been at least two times now where I felt I should have been able to easily access an area that was blocked off. Also it's really easy to get stuck between trees (never to the point of needing the restart I should say) and run for a gap thinking you can make it through but hitting an invisable wall like a fly on glass.

Still given the price and high quality of the assets, it being a little rough on the edges is something that can I can easily forgive and work with.

Running the UE4 engine, the game is visually stunning. There is a large and varied area to explore. At time running through forest, others scaling along and up mountians or going into a maze of caves. It's easy to get lost which is part of the fun, I had my compass up pretty much all the time.

If “Slender: The Arrival” made you scared of being alone in the woods at night with just a flashlight, this game might do the same for you about Russia’s Ural Mountains. It’s not about jump scares. It’s about the environment of the region, which changes as you progress in certain areas.

What makes this game difficult is not the slow-walking, semi-transparent monsters, or the orange smoke, or the primitive traps, or Sean Bean. It’s the fact that this game is a pre-GPS walking simulator. There’s no mini-map on the corner of your screen, with a dot or a triangle indicating where you are. All you have is a paper map that fills the entire screen and a compass, so it’s very easy to get lost. Fortunately, there are some places with coordinates handwritten on rock, so you can confirm where you are. Confirm or even find out you’re nowhere near where you expected to be!

Also, your character is physically limited. You can’t run for very long before losing your breath. Save the running for when you see the orange smoke or when your compass starts shaking.
The worst part is that you can’t jump nor climb. Given that you’re in a mountainous area, this can be very frustrating.

Basically, if you’re interested in the paranormal, if you like somewhat scary games, or if you’re looking for a unique experience, you should get this game. However, if you’re looking for something as scary or disturbing as “Amnesia” or “Outlast”, if you hate VERY long walks, or if you have no patience for the kind of exploration this game requires, you should stay away from it.

I suggest you only play this game in the winter. You’ll get a better feel of it that way.

reviewText:
Kholat is an horror-adventure/exploration game based on the Dyatlov Pass Incident. The tragic and mysterious event involved nine Russian hikers who ventured out to the Kholat Syakhl mountains in high hopes to climb its daunting size but, unfortunately, met an untimely end. The reasoning behind their deaths is still unsolved to this day.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f9oiz_zqHLM

What I Enjoyed:

Walk in the park - Despite the dreadful and mournful wintery setting, the game visuals are at its highest peak, creating a lot of realism and utilizing it to present a haunting experience that will surely leave players’ skins crawling. Every sway of the frosted pine trees to the brisk, snowy winds are so evident in detail that it only furthers the fear players will endure when embarking on the Dyatlov Pass trail. The title fully optimizes the immersiveness in the game by adding stunning imagery as well as sounds that results in an unpleasant yet necessary experience to grasp the terror that had befallen the nine mountaineers.

Storytelling - The game dwells deep into laying the foundation of the Dyatlov Pass incident by relishing players who have no prior knowledge to the horrific events that took place; it provides basic information while foretelling theorized depictions of what resulted on that eventful night. The story paints grotesque imagery at the beginning which hooks the player off the bat and opts for an interesting playthrough.

Simple is best - The gameplay mechanics is not meant to detract from the story or the exploration by keeping the game style simplistic, which allows it to not be the focal point of the game. While possessing the generic run, zoom, and flashlight commands, the game also introduces players to a map and compass that are unlike other games’ versions as this maps does not record your current location. Instead, this special map reveals conspiring events and potential savepoints in disguise as campfires.

What I Disliked:

Square one - The difficulty appears when players are not utilizing the map and compass effectively, which results in endless walking/running around the same dead tree stump or the same creepy, grinning totem poll. To prevent this, you must understand how to get to the desired location by locating the set of coordinates written on your map. This, unfortunately, requires some map navigational skills and proper compass usage as well as memorizing key landscape structure. Overtime, those who are prone to stubbornness (like myself) who are using these available tools prove more as an annoyance and tedious.

Turtle’s pace -  The threats in this game seems to be minimal at times. As the game implements a running command that ends so sporadically, it offers a nerve-wrecking sensation when pursued by predators but will frustrate you when simply try to find an unexplored area. This results in a whole playthrough the almost appears to go at a turtle’s pace. Players must use the running command spaciously and in spurts or risk exerting the character’s stamina. Sadly, the recovering time is longer than the running duration so plan your actions accordingly.

Conclusion:

The story of Kholat brought me through an unnerving adventure, successfully making me question every sudden sound I heard. The game did a wonderful job with the atmosphere but the endless roaming sometimes made the game feel like a walking simulation instead of a horrific adventure. Despite that, I really enjoyed the time I’ve had playing this game and found myself lost in its storytelling.

I enjoyed it but I enjoy immersive horror like this game was designed to provide.

A bit of advice for interested players:
- The order you collect notes doesn't matter, they will unlock the journal/article entries sequentially regardless of which order you find the note items in the world. - While there are mechanics that influence whether you die, I had a few occasions where I felt like I died randomly without any clear reason. This didn't detract me much, since I just loaded back in at the last note node, but I can imagine it irritating some players.
- Performance is rough. My PC is moderately high end and I was regularly getting 15fps or even lower in places.

The cautious above aside, it was a very immersive environment, visually striking with very well done, chilling audio.

reviewText:
Kholat bleeds atmosphere. The gorgeous snow covered landscapes combined with the crunching of your feet in the frozen drifts and stinging winds made me physically shiver and pull the blankets closer to my body. There's a peacefulness found in the isolation of the mountains that affected me in a very real way. I've trudged alone through wintry forests, lost in my own thought before, and Kholat recreates that feeling with near perfection. The supernatural elements may be things of folklore and imagination, but they effectively convey that awe-inspiring sense of mystery and danger that lurks in the untouched, dark wilderness.

Using the somewhat obscure but true events of a group of hikers meeting their untimely end in the Ural mountains under mysterious circumstances, Kholat charges the player to set out into the frozen Russian nothingness to uncover the truth behind the rampant speculations. You arrive in a small town with almost no guidance, trek up a pathway toward the mountains, and find a small survival tent containing a map, compass, and flashlight. These will be the only tools at your disposal for the entire game. The map has GPS coordinates scribbled in a corner, but there is no indicator to show you where you're located. You have to use landmarks and a rudimentary sense of direction to adventure toward those vague points of interest, and even then the map isn't entirely reliable as what appears to be straight pathways are often blocked or misleading. It may sound more difficult in concept than it is in practice: the environment isn't nearly as vast and open as it first appears. There are clear pathways and walls so basic maze-solving logic applies, but still, the lack of hand holding and gift of player freedom go a long way to sell the play space as untamed.

This is very much a walking simulator, and it's also a game about picking up notes. Kholat is a very good one of those experiences. It's the perfect length, ending before the wonder of exploration wears thin. It leverages the simplicity of note gathering for gameplay mechanics; you'll hear them fluttering in the wind well before you see them, so you're forced to heighten your senses which makes every wolf howl or cracking branch that much more unnerving. The notes also act as save points, so they're objects of tension relief on top of mere story dumps. There are fail states, and while the game certainly isn't difficult they come frequently and with enough unpredictability that you never let your guard down for long. It's packed with just the right amount of variety that it never becomes formulaic; you have to hide in a closet from a monster... once. There's some very light platforming, and a couple set-piece chase sequences. It's a game about the supernatural and there's a subplot about inhumane experiments, but it's best described as “tense” rather than full of jump scares or gross out blood and gore. It's the rare instance of a game understanding the strengths of the genre (horror and walking experience) and using them correctly rather than making an empty game and passing off laziness for art.

As I hiked up a narrow mountain pass I thought I caught what looked like a vaguely skull shaped rock in the mountain. Winding further upward my suspicions were confirmed as there were several giant, silent skulls staring at me. I felt uneasy, but also taken aback at the beauty and subtlety of these impossibly titanic symbols of death carved there amidst the softly falling snow. Kholat is more about the experience than traditional gameplay, but it's an experience that moved me deeply and I highly recommend it.

Kholat is an aquired taste. The extended bouts of exploration and note collecting will be tedious for some, but the environment and soundtrack are beautiful and atmospheric. The game is heavily reliant on narrative, developing the story little by little with each note that you find scattered across the desolate, snowy landscape. The voice acting is excellent and delivered with convincing emotion. You aren't completely safe on your journey, in that you'll occassionally come across enemies that will pursue you, but are not an especially difficult threat.

The game is by no means without its (rather frustrating) flaws. Progress will be slow as you cannot run for any significant amount of time before being winded. The compass/map system is confusing and will get you lost on the twisting, large map. The enemies are minor irritations and while the first couple of encounters may startle, the effect soon wears thin. There are occassional glitches that will result in your character becoming stuck in the environment or falling right through it into voids unknown.

Ultimately though, you'll want to keep searching to know what happens next, with an ending open to various interpretations. If you're patient and you like a haunting story with good atmosphere, you'll enjoy Kholat.

I must say, for a first foray into game development IMGN.PRO have created something absolutely stunning. The story (based on real events) has enough to grip you and drive you on to finding out what happens.

reviewText:
Dark, eerie and alone.

That's how to describe this game simply.

The game relies very heavily on atmosphere and as such, will be a joy on a higher end PC. The visuals are quite astonishing with the style reminding me of MW2 (Where it kind of looks like a painting). I run SLI 980's on an Asus PG278Q 1440p monitor and I get around 60 FPS on max settings. AA seems to be needed in some form in this game.

Some tips:
Always look at the map to get around. This may seem obvious but you get lost in the woods and you won't be sure which way is up or down on the map. If you look at your first camp and turn around, you are looking towards the bottom of the map. Like wise, looking towards the camp is looking towards the upper part.

The compass still confuses me and I'm not sure if the C means camp on it.

Slight spoiler:
If you encounter a monster or two, you're best bet is to run and hide or try to get by by staying away from their path. They seem to follow but if you oof it away from they don't seem to stick with you long.

You can only fast travel when you find them. to and from other camps. Camps are just like the first except they will have a fire going and another tent that isn't broken down. It makes me want to stay at a camp in one of the caves because the fire light seems to feel like false security.

Play with the best headphones you can get. It really adds to the experience.

Finally, look at the coordinates  on the left side of your map and go for those. The notes you find help for the story, but won't get you any farther necessarily. Going to camps, finding notes and finding important coordinate locations will save the game.

Look around the walls and ground. You can sometimes find coordinates on rocks and such to tell you where you are.

I'm still playing this game and it is quite good for what it is. It's just a little taxing on your PC IMO. Maybe at 1080p this won't be such a problem.

reviewText:
Kholat is a game that opens in a small Russian town covered in snow. This first area is new and unfamiliar and the game certainly doesn't lead you by the hand at all, it leaves you alone to discover the harshness of the landscape. You come to the opening of a forest and this is where the horror truly begins.

Kholat  leaves you on edge most times with the eerie noises and a sense of loneliness. The monsters you encounter resemble mere shadows that turn orange the more aggresive they become, once they are fully aware of you they will kill you causing you to start at the last save point. The story of the game will leave you wanting more as you pickup each of the notes, journal entries, or case files.

Kholat is an amazing looking game, mostly due to its rendering of the Russian wilderness. From the snow on the ground to the ghosts of pasts incidents everything is detailed and distinct. The environments are all very intricate, every single part is made to be different with markers to help you on your way. The music and sounds are possibly the best part of the game with most tracks being a haunting piano score or the sounds of the wind and storms. The attention to the sound is part of what makes the game atmospheric with little knocks and sounds of wolves making you feel like you may not be as alone as previous thought.

Kholat's weakest point is its gameplay, as certain bits of it tend to infuriate more than scare. The game's concept is a simple collect pages and avoid the monster gameplay, the problem being is your character is not really fit to navigate the landscape or run from the monsters. your character is able to look far distances, run, as well as use  one of the items you are given to navigate.

Your character cannot jump, and when he runs he can jolt for about 3 seconds before getting tired out and requiring a significant amount of time to recover. Kholat is an expansive free roam game where low stamina is a very bad thing to have and the compass you are given becomes another issue as well. The compass, initially, is a very hard item to use entirely because you end up spending half of your time figuring it out hoping something doesn't kill you while you do. A large saving grace for the game is the ability to fast travel from campsite to campsite.

I won't discuss the ending as it is something you just have to experience for yourself. DO I hate this game? No, I actually highly recommend playing it as the horror feel is always present, it's a very nerve shattering experience and it's easy to get caught up in the information the game gives you. If you enjoy games like Dear Esther and Slender: The Arrival, I recommend trying the game out, be warned though, the game can be oddly frustrating at times, and is not recommended for just one sitting.

reviewText:
I wouldn't call this game a horror game. For those of you looking for an experience like the FNAF series, Amnesia, or even Slenderman, don't buy this game.

From my impression, Kholat is a suspensefully atmospheric completionist adventure game where you experience gorgeous scenery, intense music, a haunting environment, and Sean Bean. Kholat is suspenseful, but hardly scary: jumpscares are rare and predictable, and there isn't an overabundance of horror imagery. It could be called a gateway into the horror genre for gamers who aren't comfortable with the bigger horror titles. For what Kholat gives, it does it fairy well.

Now I should give my critique of what Kholat could have done better.
-Sean Bean honestly isn't the best voice actor, neither is any of their other voice actors for the game. Not terrible, but sub-par for the atmosphere the game is trying to create.
-There's not nearly enough enemies. Overall, the Ural Mountains seem quite empty with the exception of the primary points of interest.
-A little too paranormal right off the bat. The plot flow could have been stuctured much better

Kholat is structured like a dungeon crawler, where you set off towards a  coordinate, the environment getting more and more spooky as you go, encountering some spooky creatures that try to kill you, then you reach the point of interest, find a spooky (not really) clue, and return to home base, where it's safe, then repeat until you unlock everything. Fun for some, not for everyone. The plot isn't scary, and neither is the gameplay after a few hours of exploration.

Story: 5/10
Setting: 9/10
Scariness: 6/10
Replayability: 4/10

Final Verdict: Not bad at all, but could've been a lot better. I bought it on sale, so i felt like $12 was worth it, but don't buy it for the full price. The game is beautiful, but it doesn't get any deeper as you play, and at the end you feel like you didn't really accomplish much. That said, it's still pretty fun if you take it for its face value.

7/10

I will recommend this game.

The story you piece together is hard to follow and like the actual real event, raises more questions than it answers.

Admittedly most games of this type don't offer much for gameplay, but in Kholat it just felt glaringly obvious there needed to be more going on here than just collecting paper. For instance, the map is fairly decently sized and you spend a great deal of time traversing it, but so little ever happens in it with the exception of a few easily distinguishable areas. It just got boring very quick. Why couldn't there be random/weird/creepy events or encounters in the huge empty areas to mix things up a bit? The extremely brief sprinting ability and very limited fast travel doesn't help with this much either.

Also, this game has no quick save or manual save system. So be prepared to backtrack from your last checkpoint all the way to where you accidentally died. Adding to that as well, if you're trying to be through and think you missed a path to explore and want to backtrack... Think again. This game likes to have one-way paths forcing you take the long way back around if you know you happened to miss something. Manual, player saves would fix both these issues.

Developers, stop doing only automated checkpoint saves. STOP IT.

Overall though, I liked the game. It was interesting, if a bit medicore with it's gameplay.
I would suggest giving it a try if it goes on sale if you're into these kinds of game.

reviewText:
Kholat is a horror game based off of a real life incident in Russia decades ago.  While it falters in some areas, it does some things so well that it merits a recommendation.

The game features a large open area that the player must explore.  The player has a map and a compass, but navigation is initially disorienting, something that enriches the experience. The landscape feels confusing, and mastering it is part of the challenge. The element of navigation in a unique snowy landscape brings something new to the genre.  It's the first game since Miasmata that made me feel as though I really had to pay attention to find my way around. This approach works particularly well in a horror game.

The sound and atmosphere design is amazing; snow whips and howls around the player constantly, and the baying of wolves seems to follow the player.  Occasionally, the player will navigate through narrow caves or dark forests.  Sometimes, you are not alone, and I experienced frequent dread and occasional shocks throughout my time.  The game varies the dangers you face, and I never got comfortable. Finally, it should be mentioned that the entire game is gorgeous.

The plot, however, features a number of themes-supernatural, government conspiracy, to name the most prominent- and mashes them together. The story does not tie together all of these ideas in a cohesive manner.  The voice acting works well, but everything is so scattered that it didn't hold my interest.  The considerable talent of Sean Bean is not utilized well. It's one of those approaches to horror that's designed to 'leave it to the player's interpretation,' but there's nothing solid to hold on to.  Nothing comes together, and the ending is insubstantial.

Had the story elements been more focused, this would have been a stronger recommendation.  However, the gameplay of navigation in a blizzzard, the incredible atmosphere, and the consistent chills, make this a worthy choice for anyone looking for a quality horror title.

reviewText:
I recommend Kholat for its story, and only its story.

Kholat's premise is based around the events of the Dyatlov Pass incident, in which 9 hikers died in the Ural mountains from an unknown cause. Throughout the course of the game the player will explore the treacherous mountain landscape, hoping to uncover the answer as to what truely caused the hiker's deaths.
Like most mystery based horror games as you start to uncover answers you'll also find more questions arise from your investigation which keeps you going until you reach a rather ambiguous ending. Unlike my previous attempts to play these sort of games, this one actually managed to hold my interest to the very end, and the ending itself made me want to go back through it and potentially uncover more information.
There's also some terrific performances by the voice actors in this game. Sean Bean's narration along with the voices from logbook/diary entries really flow well with the tonal shift of the story as the player progresses. And the ambient audio/music help keep the tension going as you get lost in the endless sea of trees and rocks.
In terms of actual gameplay, my favorite thing is that the map is an actual map. Player's have to read coordinates and use a compass in order to know where they are located in the world instead of having a little dot on a mini-map showing their exact location. This really helps to put the player in an explorer mindset and really keep track of their surroundings. Its just a shame the surrounding environment is what almost kills this game for me.
The environment, apart from a few key locations, is visually bland, poorly optimized, and riddled with so many bugs that I could never get truely immersed in the experience. The environment just feels too big and empty. Bugs included huge amounts of clipping, stretched textures, environment pieces popping in/out of existence, and sometimes the entire floor disappearing resulting in my character falling out of the environment to my death. Of all the things in this game that needed more attention, it would be the design of the evironment and the rest of the gameplay.
As I said earlier, the map function was an interesting design choice and one that I liked, my problem is the rest of the gameplay is just a walking/running simulator. As a player, nothing makes me feel more constrained and limited than being blocked by a 2 foot tall rock that I should be able to just jump/climb over but the game won't allow me to. I'm just asking to be able to interact with the environment and not feel like I'm trapped on a linear path surrounded by invisible walls.
My other problem is the monsters. While there are story clues as to what/who they are, they didn't really add to the tension and in fact felt more like an obligation because its a horror game

reviewText:
Kholat is a horror game developed by IMGN.PRO. The game is based on the true-event known as the Dyatlov Pass Incident. In Kholat players take on the role of some person walking through the mountains and collecting notes and avoiding some teleporting/slow-moving entity (very similar to Slender) all while being narrated by the ever-famous, man who always dies, Sean Bean. The notes you are collecting are supposed to reveal the story and events around the Dyatlov Pass Incident but there really doesn’t seem to be much of a story present in Kholat and it feels more like the developers didn’t exactly know what they were doing and decided to just adopt the tired, and stale Slender formula we’ve been seeing in indie-horror titles as of late, which is a huge bummer coming from Kholat.

Basing a game around the events of the Dyatlov Pass Incident should be a solid premise, and make an amazing horror game but that doesn’t exactly happen when you dip into Kholat. Instead you get a pretty boring, and frustrating game that feels like a chore to progress through, and doesn’t offer much in terms of excitement or enjoyment. You’re thrown into an ‘open-world’ environment that looks gorgeous, I won’t deny that. Kholat is one damn good looking game, thanks to Unreal Engine 4 and the amazing environmental work that was done on the game. The mountains look foreboding, and unnerving especially when I came across two giant skulls carved into the face of a cliff. Sadly, that’s about all that Kholat really offers in term of a horror experience. Through-out my time spent with the game I really only found myself feeling creeped out by certain parts of the environment. The enemies weren’t exactly terrifying, and were more so frustrating, or downright annoying to deal with. They work pretty similar to how Slenderman works. A slow-moving, possible teleporting (it seems like they can teleport in front of you which is downright annoying) entity that stalks you the entire time while you collect notes. Seem familiar? That’s the core concept of Kholat in a nut-shell. Explore a creepy environment, collect notes, and avoid the entity that is stalking you. Even the entity seems to be confused during the game as well. I often found myself watching the entity stop chasing me and just stand still, or change direction and start walking away from me. Where’s the fear in that? And you’re most likely to be killed by the environment, which offers no sort of warning when you could die. It’s more like a random, gotcha sort of incident which is horrible. Kholat doesn’t exactly bring anything fresh, or new to the table in terms of an experience, which again is a bummer considering how good Kholat could of been.

The game also allows you to fast-travel at campsites that you discover which is a glorious feature that I’m glad was implemented due to how agonizing, and boring it is to traverse the environment after a while. This mainly stems from doing a ton of backtracking, and walking in circles. Then again, this could be intentional due to the disorienting environment and this could possible be what the victims of the real-life incident felt before their untimely demise. Sadly, it doesn’t work and just makes the game boring and again, feel like more of a chore to play. That and the entire movement system in the game is pretty godawful. You can sprint for what is maybe a few seconds before tiring out and moving at an extremely sluggish pace and it takes a fair bit of time to be able to sprint again. It makes the moments where you need to run-away from the entities, and the “orange fog” that tends to chase you to be frustrating. It feels like this was intended to make players feel tense and scared but all I felt was severe annoyance, which isn’t a good thing. You want players to have fun, and feel terrified. Not annoyed, and angry at poorly designed mechanics.

I’ve only put around 3 hours into Kholat and I can tell I’m nearing the end-game area. The story seems to be expanding, but is still extremely convoluted with no real direction. What am I doing in the mountain? Why did I decide to come here? Who the hell are these entities walking around? The game offers really no explanation for anything, and even Sean Bean seems like he didn’t want to be there, and maybe even he too was confused by the entire ordeal.

In the end, would I recommend Kholat? That depends. At $21.99 (currently on sale for $19.79) I wouldn’t. Maybe if the game were to drop to around $10 I’d be happy telling people to pick it up, but I don’t feel comfortable recommending a bare and a non-enjoyable experience like this for that kind of a price-point. Kholat had a solid premise, and some unique concepts but it sort of failed to deliver. It has amazing visuals, and the setting is great but it really just falls flat on delivery.
Pros

Awesome setting, and based off of a spooky real-life event with the Dyatlov Pass Incident.
Gorgeous visuals, and at times can feel really uneasy while traversing through the snow-ridden, blizzard like environments.
Sandbox-ish?

Cons

Not much meat to the game. More of a Slender clone by walking around, gathering notes, and avoiding some slow-walking/teleporting entity.
Sean Bean’s narration feels a tad phoned in.
The story is extremely convoluted, and the game doesn’t really have any sense of direction.
The game is more frustrating then it is fun. The deaths you experience are more so random, and put on a more luck-based feel. Maybe you’ll randomly get killed by the environment with no warning.
Doesn’t exactly feel like a horror game, and more so feels like an adventure narrative sort of experience in the veins of Dear Esther.

Sadly, Kholat just isn’t all that great of a game and for that price-point I’d recommend you check it out if it gets a price drop. I was really excited for Kholat as I’m super into the Dyatlov Pass Incident, but the game didn’t fully utilize what it could of with these events and sort of just falls flat.

Based on real events, in Kholat you are going to be exploring the icy, snowy Russian wilderness looking for answers regarding what happened to a group of students who died under mysterious circumstances.

-Game looks fantastic. Just solid graphics all around and there is some serious visual FX wizardry in this game that make it a lot of fun to explore.
-Music and SFX are top notch. Holy crap.
-Some really scary moments. Pretty nice to have for a horror game and all.
-HUGE map. Tons to see.
-Freedom to explore where you want, when you want; kind of like the horror version of Skyrim.
-Great environmental storytelling with narrated notes and such.
-Not in a mental hospital. A fairly unique setting for this kind of game and it's nice to get some variety.

Cons:
-Non linear gameplay may be a turnoff to folks that want to be thrust into the action/scares
-The map takes some serious getting used to as it doesn't show your position (but does offer limited fast travel options as you play and find campsites and shows discovered landmarks)
-Not being able to jump feels limiting
-Frame rate dropped occasionally when a lot of effects were on the screen at once
-Died falling into a 2 foot deep pit without much explanation as to why that killed me. Probably because I can't jump making that a death sentence.

All in all I think you'll have a great time with this game! I can't wait to finish my play through and see how things work out for our mysterious protagonist and learn what happened to the students. :)

reviewText:
If the graphics was the only thing that mattered, then Kholat would be a tremendous success. Seriously the game looks beautiful (especially for an indie open world game). But the most important thing is the gameplay and this game is sadly severely lacking in content. The world is absolutely barren, there is nothing but you and the ocasional shadowy figure which kills you instantly if you come too close. You are no fighter, you even lack the ability to jump, which prevents you from entering areas, which any normal human being should be able to access. The only thing you are allowed to do is collecting diary pages and notes, which gradually unveils the story. Collecting notes is also one of two ways to save the game (the other is fast travel), so it is entirely possible to scout out a large portion of the map without saving only to die and have to do it all over again. Combine this with an absolutely dreadful map system and you have a very irritating game. Yes, you have a map, but it's inefficient at best. It doesn't show your position and you cannot put any notes on it (missed opportunity). Sometimes you find coordinates, which tells you your position. But all this effort just isn't worth it, I ditched the map very quickly and managed relatively fine, I mean the world isn't that big. Way to make a big portion of the game irrelevant.

Running is as you might have already figured out your main activity in this game. But your stamina is very very low, run for too long and your wision becomes blurry, which forces you to stop. So learning how to sprint in short bursts becomes essential. Let's return to the shadows/ghosts or whatever they are. They are very easy to see, because they leave behind bright orange footsteps. But sneaking around them can be tricky because there is no stealth system, one time I've been hidden in a bush and was detected, other time I stood in plain sight an wasn't detected. So the only thing that triggers their AI is proximity. Keep your distance and they will never be a threat to you. But if you trigger them, you can run away from them, if you react quickly. Hovewer, this usually involves running away from the direction you were going, and you might end up in a completely different area then you wanted to. This is probably the only time, where the coordinates scatered throughout the world will actually come in handy.

So, we've established that this game doesn't offer too much in the gameplay area, the main focus must be the story. The story, which is told throughout the notes, it ranges from diary pages of the Dyatlov expedition, to insane ramblings which make everything more confusing. Instead of bringing answers, everything you read/witness raises more questions. It does hovewer a decent job describing the Dyatlov incident at the beginning.

Let's sum this up- this game lacks in gameplay, lacks in storytelling, the map system is tedious, the world looks nice but is completely empty. You have to ask yourself, is that worth the asking price?

reviewText:
The full (German) review can be found here: http://www.jack-reviews.com/2015/06/kholat-review.html

Kholat is an open world horror game that immerses players in a wasteland that truly feels alive. Wind blows past your ears; snow falls in varying degrees of intensity, sometimes robbing your sight; mysterious beings howl in the distance; an old bridge creaks dangerously when you walk over it...
And whenever you find certain notes you'll witness a paranormal phenomenon that is certainly worth witnessing ... which is something that I cannot say about the rest of the game.

The incident it's based on is already the most interesting aspect of the entire story, whereas most of the notes I found told me nothing of importance. Some are written by the people who died, some by a guy who tried to find out what happened, and then there are theories trying to explain the incident. Once in a while, you will also hear Sean Bean's character calling out to you, mentioning things that happened long ago. He seems to have some plans for the nameless protagonist … but when the game fades to black only a minute into the final act, you will be none the wiser, as the game doesn't really try to explain anything ... or have a resolution ... or anything that could be called an ending.

Is the gameplay worth it, at least? No, not when you spend most of the time walking around aimlessly, always hoping to find whatever it is that the coordinates on your map are meant to signify. Sure, you might say that feeling lost is kinda the point, but not when it's so annoying that you'd rather stop playing than trudge on endlessly.

It could have been less annoying if the map was actually useful, but unless you're standing in front of a camp (which serves as a fast-travel-point), you'll have no idea where the hell you are. And even then you might have trouble charting your course. And if you happen to run into a monster (none of which are scary) and haven't found a camp or note in a while, then you're going to be screwed, as there are no manual saves. The first time it happened (when I didn't even know that enemies existed), I had to start over from the other side of the map.

Therefore, I can only recommend Kholat to those who like to explore the beautiful environment. Everyone else will be sorely disappointed by the lack of interesting gameplay or a story worth following.

reviewText:
I only have one more location to explore in Kholat, but I think I've played enough and got enough out of the game that I'm a position to do a review.  It's not going to be around much longer (victory is near!).  I've gotten alot of notes, reports and journals but might finish the game with a few missed, although I think I've gotten enough out of the story.  Also have all but one tent location it seems.  Anyways, time for a review!

This is a pretty solid survival/adventure game.  Kholat is somewhat creepy, tense and grinding because of the atmosphere, constant snow and chase sequences.  It does have a couple of good jumps and a few areas are downright intense because you're racing against time to keep out of the clutches of an instant death mist that's chasing you.  So the gist of the gameplay is that you're running around on a snow-covered mountain where things aren't as they seem and a bunch of supernatural goings on are occuring trying to piece the a story together by collecting as much written information as you can.  The last folks that traversed this mountainous impasse didn't make it back alive to tell their story.

The game isn't flawless that's for sure, but I enjoyed alot of it.  It's like a point and click adventure with light elements of Amnesia and Outlast, because you can die and you will die as you trial n' error your way to each key location.  The game is immersive enough that you really feel like you're lost in the mountains, freezing to death and all around completely ******.  After some frustration I was able to successfully use the map to figure out where I was at and where I needed to go.  You basically gather your bearings at different base camps before setting out on the next hunt for reports, diaries and journals.  Along the way you will traverse mountains, valleys, forests, stumble on a few signs of where life once was and encounter numerous one hit obstacles that will render you dead,

The graphics and atmosphere are great.  This game grinds in much of the way that the highly underrated Cursed Mountain did and feels a bit like John Carpenter's The Thing.  The landscapes are beautiful to behold and even though the map is not quite as huge and daunting as you initially think, there's a good sense of vastness and scope that really puts you into the heart of adventure.  The story unfolds in semi-confusing bits of prose narrated by Sean Bean, a female actor and yourself.  Due to the difficulty of travel, there is a sense of accomplishment when you successfully reach new locations and landmarks, and even though the pace is a ruthless slow burn, it's dangerous and fun.  The map/compass system is challenging.  As a dogged old school gamer I figured it out with no videos, walkthroughs or otherwise and it took me time.  This game makes you feel lost, isolated and generally f*cked but the more you play and discover things, the more the map fills in and becomes easier to navigate.

Sound design deserves a special mention here because it's probably creepier than the actual evil spirits you're up against.  You will hear different cues providing clues to what situations, discoveries and key locations are nearby.  As I first played the game I found myself running everytime I heard one of these sounds thinking I was about to be attacked.  Eventually, I figured out that these were things I was supposed to stop and take notice of, so keep your ears open while playing this one (not just for monsters!).  Never before in a game did I get friggen excited over the sound of a rustling piece of paper, but Kholat makes you yearn for minute pleasures.  These cues also provide the location of game saving tents and I had no crashes or problems in terms of saving (knock on wood) 5 hours into the game thus far.  Though glitches do occur.

Unfortunately, Kholat is not without its negatives.  While the save system wasn't a problem for me and was just spaced out enough for my liking, prepare for some cheap deaths.  As an adventurer, I think it was a little bit silly that you couldn't jump.  I do understand that not being able to jump made travel more difficult, but it was somewhat nagging when you couldn't hurdle a two foot ledge.  I died a decent amount during Kholat.  Sometimes warranted and sometimes very cheaply.  I stepped on a ghosts head that was stuck in the ground because of a glitch, died descending ledges that the game didn't want you to go down and ended up dead because the game would be playing smoothly one minute with alot going on and lagging like hellfire the next.  Though I never lost large amounts of progress, there are certainly some ludicrous things that will kill you, so prepare to do things over a few times even if the cause of your demise was completely out of your control.

Though some runs for key story pages are tense and exciting (the forest), the enemies are kinda stupid.  There is no stealth system whatsoever to avoid them.  They killed me far away and out of sight, chased me to the ends of areas and other irritating stuff.  You can stun them with your flashlight, but it's never worth it.  The spirits don't provide too many problems and can be easily avoided the majority of the time, yet other times you will die at their hands while cursing the very mountain you're climbing.  They weren't a particularly interesting opponent either and sometimes were so stupid they wouldn't bother you if you walked by them right in their field of view.  The whole system was somewhat poorly implemented in my opinion and definitely a major buzzkill on the tension.  A few other cheap one hit kills will take you down.  For example, I got hit by the same falling rock 3 times a row, and whether I'd wait, rush or run, the game would lag up and I'd get killed.  I passed that part by luck and luck alone.  Thankfully, none of this stuff puts you so far backwards that it's game-breaking, just rather cheap, laggy and poorly conceived.

The story is solidly narrated but is mostly confusing.  Those hammy diatribes and goofy bits of poetry don't make much sense even if Bean did a good job with the narration.  It just doesn't make alot of sense and I found myself less involved with what was going on with each passing journal page instead of becoming more intensely engrossed.  Despite the story being rather overblown and not so well-written, the desire to push on and see what location is ahead more than made up for the yarn not pulling the gamer in as much as it should.

Overall, Kholat has been an enjoyable experience and I'm looking forward to wrapping it up either later tonight or tomorrow.  I don't think the couple of things left to do would change my score drastically, because I know endings are not usually all they're cracked up to be and it's the gameplay itself that concerns me.  Did I have fun playing Kholat?  Yes.  Was it a perfect game?  No.  Will I pick it up a second time fro the beginning?  No.  But do I regret spending the money?  No, not at all!  A good horror themed game for players that would rather the scares come from the atmosphere than a bunch of silly jump-gimmicks.  Pure adventure fans might find it worth a look as well.

Here's the breakdown:

Pros:

-Excellent graphics
-Sound design is not only top-notch but important for gameplay
-Solid voice acting
-Overbearing sense of dread and isolation like a good horror flick
-Exploration is mostly fun
-Cool compass/map system (You really do feel like you're lost and trying to find your way)
-Some solid set-pieces and chase sequences

Cons
-Laggy gameplay can lead to cheap deaths
-Boring enemies with awful AI will either stupidly ignore you or murder you ruthlessly
-Muddled story
-Could use more actions (jump, climb)
-Limited tasks/objectives leads to some tedium late game
-No stealth system when stealth is part of your mission

Overal rating:  7.5/10

reviewText:
I'd definitely recommend Kholat for any fan of survival horror - the environment is beautifully haunting, the creaks and moans of the forest will make your heart pound (play with headphones!), and there is an intriguingly dark story that will keep you hunting for more answers.

That said, this immersive experience could have been vastly improved by tending to some missed opportunities - first and foremost being environmental puzzles. This game is purely a horrific adventure of discovery, which I did enjoy, but felt some simple yet brain twisting environmental puzzles would have made the beautiful and chilling environment even more intimate, and would have slowed down the pace of the gameplay while also making it more dynamic.

Enemies (or I should say enemy) could have also used some dynamism. Once the enemy is aware of you, there's really no getting away or hiding unless you just keep sprinting as much as you can until you get even more lost. I did like that you couldn't fight the enemy and that getting away was difficult, but encountering them would have been much more interesting if I had more opportunities to hide.

Lastly, there were some missed opportunities in the environment itself. There are a few wonderful scripted moments when you walk up to an abandoned radio tower, a burnt forest, a rotting church, but when you get to these awesomely dark scenes you just grab the note and get the hell out of there - I wanted to spend more time in these places (*cough* environmental puzzles *cough*).

People complain about the compass and map in this game, but I think this is one of its most immersive qualities and an impressive way to bring a subtle level of strategy and skill into the game - I wanted more elements like this!

Overall I felt this was a great survival horror experience and was well worth the price, but could have been a legendary survival horror experience if more elements of the game were developed, like the absence of environmental puzzles and more ways of dealing with the game's enemy.
