reviewText:
Kholat is a survival horror game based on true events that took place in Russia decades ago, when hikers were found dead for unknown reasons. The game begins without further introductions to its lead character, whose identity or motivation are never revealed during the game. Then, Kholat turns into a mountain hiking game as we take such mysterious character to find some notes spread on the mountain are - that's the best part of the game. The scenarios look stunning and the sound effects, plus the great musical score creates one hell of an atmosphere. It's possible to walk for a long time and get completely lost amidst all the snow and rocks; the game is truly disorienting, which increases the immersion. Also, considering the player has to get through everything using only a map and a compass (which I never figured out how to use), it makes for a very challenging experience, but very fun nonetheless.

Each note found, reveals a little (very little) more about what has been happening in the region during the last century, including the real life event. The supernatural elements are heavily based on Lovecraft - people dreaming about a powerful, nightmarish being from another dimension and going insane - however, the in game supernatural elements are completely random and off tone with the rest of the game. The shadows, who are the main 'enemies' on the game, have no pattern at all. Sometimes you can just sprint next to them and poof, he's gone. Besides of the lack of coherence when it comes about the supernatural elements, the invisible barriers were the most annoying bits of Kholat. There are lots of moments when you are forced to walk a lot to find a new way, when the character could have easily jumped a rock, a feat which clearly any average human being would have been to pull off. Except the protagonist of Kholat.

The game lenght is very short - it took me around 6 hours to finish it getting almost every note (missed a few). But the truth is, if you don't feel like mountain hiking and being scared by wolves (wolves were the scariest part of the game, even though they only howl and never show up), this game might be really boring. I recommend it but with some reservations.

7/10 (Good)

reviewText:
Have you ever heard of the story behind a group of missing Russian students in the Northern Ural Mountains of Russia? Based on a true story, Kholat delves into the chilling story of those missing students. Filled with horror, the supernatural, and incredibly unnerving environments; Kholat takes you on a crazy journey that’ll leave you questioning why the hell you decided to play it at night time with only a lamp to light up your small room…

For those loyal GameReviewsAU fans out there, you’ll probably have learnt we like games that genuinely freak us out rather than ones that rely on jump-scares.

Kholat does a great job of being genuinely freaky by placing you in the middle of a relentless blizzard with only a map, compass and torch to help you get around. There are jump-scares, but because they’re so spaced out, you’re always left unprepared for what is waiting for you around the bend.

Backstory
For gamers out there who don’t know the events that transpired in those freezing Ural Mountains, here’s a little excerpt taken from Wikipedia.

The incident involved a group of nine experienced ski hikers from the Ural Polytechnical Institute who had set up camp for the night on the slopes of Kholat Syakhl. Investigators later determined that the skiers had torn their tents from the inside out. They fled the campsite, probably to escape an imminent threat. Some of them were barefoot, under heavy snowfall. The bodies showed signs of struggle; Dyatlov had injuries to his right fist, as if he had been in a fist fight. One victim had a fractured skull and another was found with brain damage without any sign of distress to the skull. One of the skull fractures was so severe it was determined that he would not have been able to move. Additionally, one woman’s tongue was missing. Soviet authorities determined that an “unknown compelling force” had caused the deaths; access to the region was consequently blocked for hikers and adventurers for three years after the incident. – Dyatlov Pass Incident: Wikipedia[en.wikipedia.org]

Sounds pretty damn scary right? To this day, no one knows what happened up there. So here’s where the creative minds at IMGN.PRO join up to give us a truly spine-chilling experience in Kholat.

Compass – Check, Map – Check, Torch – Check
Armed with only a map, compass and torch you are tasked with exploring the massive area where the tragedy occurred and finding out what happened to the missing students. One of the best parts of Kholat is that the exploration is completely non-linear. You can go wherever you want at any point of the game. So long as you can read a map that is.

On your map are sets of co-ordinates. These indicate places of interest in the mountains such as camp sites. Other such places of interest can be found purely by chance or by finding extra co-ordinates that have been etched into the side of rocks. These co-ordinates can take you to notes that document diary entries by the students, reports of supernatural occurrences and the like.

Your compass is a bit pointless I found. As for one: I couldn’t work out which end of the needle was North or South, and two being that you can work out where you are with the map by itself.

In Kholat, there is no mini-map. There is no marker saying “You are here”. All you have is a map with highlighted paths drawn to show you which parts of the mountain are accessible. Only once you’ve found a place of interest will it appear on your map for reference.

You also have a survival guide that gives you some suggestions on how best to navigate the treacherous environment, as well as being a place to record previously found diary entries, reports, logs etc.

However, the survival guide can be a bit misleading. For example, the guide suggests, “Before setting off for a longer journey, rest in the camp“. Reading this made me think there must be some kind of stamina system which requires you to rest at a campsite before being able to set off again. That wasn’t the case though, as you can journey around the entire map without needing a single rest apart from regaining your breath after a sprint. Instead, what the campsites do is act as fast-travel points.

Sprinting is quite limited and, if you use sprint to it’s full extent, will leave you moving very slowly and not being able to see clearly. Therefore you really need to use sprint scarcely in case you get chased by anything.

What chases you? I still don’t know but they’re scary b*stards! They look like shadowy figures that walk around in the dark and leave behind glowing orange footprints. If you get too close, they’ll give chase and not stop until you’ve either outrun them, or they catch you and end your life. Sound effects alert you to when there’s one nearby, and also if it’s started chasing you, or disappeared because you outran it.

There’s no way to defeat them because you are completely unarmed except for a torch. “Maybe the torch can shine some light on what they are?” I hear you ask. Nope… Shine the torch on them and they’ll get slightly annoyed. Well not really slightly, more like p*ssed off to the extent that they chase and kill you.

Aesthetic Charm
Kholat is powered by Unreal Engine 4, giving us incredibly high quality graphics. For an environment that is completely covered by a blizzard you’d think there’s not much point to be so detailed, but IMGN.PRO have done an incredible job with giving us such an HD mountain to explore!

Sound-wise, the howling blizzard screaming all round you whilst in the mountains never becomes repetitive and keeps your ears pricked up for other sounds, such as rustling paper, which indicates a note is nearby.

Sean Bean even makes an appearance as the narrator of the story. Every now and then you’ll reach an area where Sean pipes in with his two cents worth of narration. It’s very comforting to hear a familiar voice when you’re up to your knees in snow at a place where a group of people went nuts. But his words aren’t very comforting…

Final Thoughts
Kholat is a true adventure game, placing you in a deserted mountain with only a map, compass and torch. I love that you don’t have a minimap because it forces you to use your noggin and work out where you are with only the few tools at your disposal.

Finishing Kholat one hundred percent will take around four to six hours depending on how generous you are with sprinting. There’s a good lot of achievements to unlock, so completionists may take an extra hour or so finding out how to unlock them.

I absolutely love the graphics, sound effects and narration by Sean Bean and had an absolute blast sh*tting myself by playing at midnight with little light source. I can’t wait to get back in and find the rest of the hair-raising reports to get a better idea of what transpired during the Dyatlov Pass Incident.

reviewText:
Just take a gander at my avatar. Then my name. Is there any question as to why I would be interested in such a game?

On top of that, I am quite a fan of horror games, and atmosphere is key to their success. So when an atmospheric horror game narrated by Sean Bean comes along, well, my knees go weak.

No, the entire thing wasn’t going to rhyme. What a senseless review that would be.

Alright, so step one, how is its atmosphere? It is very well done. I’ve had some of the biggest jumps I’ve had in a considerable amount of time playing this game, and that can directly be attributed to the atmosphere. It builds up a slow anticipation at nearly all times due to a wonderful use of sounds and environment, until, like a spring, the tension snaps and you jump. Now, would I call it scary? Not quite. Moreso chilling. Heh. Cause it's cold. But really, it doesn't make you feel like Amnesia, Outlast, or other such good games make you feel. Those games, I could only get a maximum of 30 minutes (and often much less) before I'd just have to stop and take a break.

The voice acting was good, not great. Well, except for Sean Bean. I didn’t feel as if the sense of dread or horror were adequately portrayed in some of the acting. They sounded almost calm when talking about fear and losing their minds.
The gameplay isn’t anything new. I never liked the term “walking simulator” but this is the type of game that will get that term. You find notes left behind and campfires (which you can fast travel between. Didn’t know that for the first half of the game. More walking. Yay!) that slowly uncover the story. So if you’re thinking “well, that’s nothing new,” you’re absolutely right! And if you ever played Amnesia a Machine for Pigs or SOMA, you’ll be delighted (not) to find that this game too flashes your flashlight when an enemy is near (and jiggles the compass). Why, oh why does this exist. Please stop implementing this awful feature into horror games. I cannot fathom why anyone thinks it’s a good idea. “Oh, you know sounds you’re hearing? They mean nothing. Nope, still nothing. Oh hey, now somethings there! Quick, run!” It definitely lessened the experience.

I didn’t want a huge paragraph, so here’s a new one. One last gameplay mechanic I wanted to mention, and that is the navigation. You have a map and a compass that you can use to navigate the world. Use them. Don’t wander aimlessly.

The story was alright. It was based on a real incident. Not too memorable. What was it about again? Ghosts?

Overall, I enjoyed the game. The other reviewers seem to have taken much longer, and I wonder why. Was it poor navigation? Did they replay it, and to what end? I don’t see any replay value with the game, unless it unknowingly unlocked a new mode. Or perhaps they wanted all of the achievements.

But yes, overall, good, not great. Stupid idiotic flashing light.

reviewText:
Kholat was a complete mystery to me, another game which completely fell under the radar, well, mine anyway until I noticed it advertised on here a few weeks ago.

A quick look at the synopsis and the positive Steam reviews persuaded me to buy it, as did my brief demo with an 'educational' version.

Suffice to say this is one of the most compelling and gripping horror survival/mystery games you will play for some time, although it is far from perfect.

Making exceptional use of the Unreal Engine 4, Kholat is based on supposed true events of a group of mountaineers who went missing in the location of the game's name, before a rescue crew went out in search of them and found only their remains, with massive questions over what happened, given the nature of exactly what was found.

That is the premise, and it makes for a good one - you are a mystery character who explores the locale, discovers journals and articles which give more information about what really happened here, all the while being pursued by an entity whose original is equally unclear.

The entity, I should add, is nowhere near as irritating as the Slender types who ended up saturating horror games - it's a chilling enemy but doesn't appear more than it should, and boo scares are more or less absent.

Meanwhile you explore the Russian wilderness, which, btw, is completely covered in snow and the weather effects of blizzards are some of the best you'll see - up there with The Witcher, trying to find more evidence and clues; your navigation is deliberately difficult - there is no waypoint ala Witcher or GTAV - only a barely understandable compass and a physical map which contains coordinates of interest and marks places you have already been - but it doesn't really help you find where you're going, and this helps add to the complete sense of isolation in this sad and disturbing part of the world - you feel truly alone, and lost, and extremely vulnerable. And it works very well.

Yes, in places it gets a little frustrating when you truly have no clue what to do next, but it's a rare game I've enjoyed without having the answers spoonfed.

In terms of the story, it's complex - there are answers, but they too aren't spoonfed - you have to decide for yourself what happened based on how you interpret the journals.

The ending itself is poor - pure and simple - it makes little sense and is a bit of a cop out, but the flesh was in all the stuff in between and there's where you can build the picture from.

On a technical level, Kholat makes beautiful use of UE4 - it's a stunning looking game for an Indie title, not unlike Ethan Carter, also UE3 and 4. It does struggle in places with poor optimisation (1080P occasionally stuttered on 980Ti SLI) but it's forgiveable.

You'll play worse games than this, just don't expect it all wrapped up in a nice bow for you.
